I do not repent and never shall repent of what I did, as my only desire was for your welfare, the welfare of your soul; but now I see that I have not succeeded.
No me arrepiento ni me arrepentiré nunca de lo hecho.
Sólo quería una cosa: el bien de usted, la paz de su alma.
Tell me yourself what would give you real happiness and peace of mind!
Y veo que no lo he conseguido.
Dígame usted misma que es lo que puede procurarle la dicha y la paz del espíritu.
I submit myself entirely to your wishes and sense of justice.'
Me entrego a su voluntad y a sus sentimiento de justicia.
Oblonsky returned the letter and went on looking at his brother-in-law with the same amazement, not knowing what to say.
Esteban Arkadievich devolvió la carta a su cuñado y siguió contemplándole perplejo sin saber qué decirle.
That silence was so disconcerting to both that Oblonsky's lips twitched painfully as he silently and fixedly gazed at Karenin's face.
Aquel silencio era tan penoso para los dos que por los labios de Oblonsky pasó un temblor dolorido.
Sin apartar la mirada del rostro de Karenin, continuaba callando.
'That is what I wanted to tell her,' said Karenin as he turned away.
–Eso es lo único que puedo decir –habló Alexey Alejandrovich volviendo la cabeza.
'Yes, yes!' said Oblonsky, tears choking him and preventing his reply.
–Sí, sí ––dijo Esteban Arkadievich, sin fuerzas para contestar, sintiendo que los sollozos se agolpaban a su garganta–.
'Yes, yes, I understand you,' he brought out at last.
Sí, sí, lo comprendo... –pronunció al fin.
'I must know what she wants,' said Karenin.
–Deseo saber lo que ella quiere –repuso Karenin.
'I am afraid she does not understand her position herself.
–Temo que ella misma no comprenda su propia situación.
She is no judge of it,' replied Oblonsky, growing more composed.
Ahora no puede ser juez...
'She is crushed, literally crushed by your generosity.
Está consternada... sí, consternada por tu grandeza de alma...
If she reads this letter she will not have the strength to say anything – she will only hang her head lower than ever.'
Si lee esta carta, no sabrá qué decir, salvo inclinar la cabeza con más humillación aún.
'Yes, but under these circumstances how is an explanation to be arrived at?...
–Sí, mas, ¿qué puedo hacer entonces?
¿Cómo explicar...?
How am I to find out what she wishes?'
¿Cómo saber lo que quiere?
'If you will permit me to express my opinion, I think it is for you to say what you think should be done in order to put an end to this state of affairs.'
–Si me permites exponerte mi opinión, creo que depende de ti adoptar las medidas que encuentres necesarias para resolver esta situación.
'Then you think that an end should be put to it?'
Karenin interrupted him.
–¿De modo que crees que hay que acabar con este estado de cosas? –interrumpió Karenin–.
'But how?' he added, moving his hands before his eyes in a manner unusual with him.
Pero ¿cómo? –añadió, pasándose la mano ante los Ojos, con ademán insólito en él–.
'I don't see any possible way out.'
No veo salida posible.
'There is a way out of every situation,' said Oblonsky, rising and growing excited.
–Todas las situaciones tienen salida –afirmó Esteban Arkadievich, levantándose, animado ya–.
'There was a time when you wished to break with her...
Hubo un momento en que tú quisiste romper...
Should you be now convinced that you cannot make each other mutually happy...'
Si estás convencido de que es imposible haceros mutuamente dichosos...
'Happiness can be defined so differently!
–La felicidad puede comprenderse de diferentes modos...
However, I am ready to agree to anything – I want nothing at all.
Pero supongamos que estoy conforme con todo y que no quiero nada.
What way out is there, in our case?'
¿Qué salida puede tener nuestra situación?

'If you wish to know my opinion,' said Oblonsky with the same soothing, almondy-tender smile with which he had addressed Anna – a kindly smile so convincing that Karenin, conscious of his own weakness and yielding to it, was involuntarily ready to believe anything Oblonsky should say, – 'she would never say so, but there is one way out, one thing she might wish!
–¿Quieres saber mi opinión? –repuso Esteban Arkadievich, con la misma sonrisa de aceite de almendras que empleara al hablar con Ana.

Y aquella sonrisa era tan persuasiva y bondadosa que, notando involuntariamente su propia debilidad, Alexey Alejandrovich, sugestionado por ella, se sintió dispuesto a creer cuanto le dijera su cuñado. –Ana no lo dirá nunca –continuó Oblonsky–.
It would be, to terminate your relations and everything that reminds her of them.
Pero sólo hay una salida posible; sólo hay algo que ella puede desear.
As I look at it, in your case it is necessary to clear up your newly-arisen relation to one another.
And this new relation can only be established when both are free.'
Y es la interrupción de vuestras relaciones y de los recuerdos unidos a ellas.
Creo que en vuestra situación es preciso aclarar las ulteriores relaciones recíprocas, relaciones que sólo pueden establecerse basándose en la libertad de ambas partes.
'Divorce!'
Karenin interrupted with disgust.
–O sea el divorcio ––dijo, con repugnancia, Karenin. –Sí, a mi juicio sí; el divorcio –repitió, sonrojándose, Esteban Arkadievich–.
'Yes, divorce, I think.
Yes, divorce,' Oblonsky answered, reddening.
Es, en todos los sentidos, la mejor salida para un matrimonio que se halla en vuestra situación.
'That would be the most reasonable way, from every point of view, with a couple placed as you are.
¿Qué puede hacerse cuando los esposos encuentran imposible vivir juntos?
What is to be done if they find out that life together has become impossible, as might happen anywhere?'
Es algo que puede sucederle a todo el mundo...
Karenin sighed heavily and closed his eyes.
Alexey Alejandrovich, respirando penosamente, cerró los ojos. –Aquí sólo puede haber una consideración: ¿desea o no uno de los cónyuges contraer nuevo matrimonio?
'There is only one thing to consider: does either party wish to remarry?
Si no se desea, la cosa es muy sencilla ––continuó Esteban Arkadievich, sintiéndose cada vez más dueño de sí.
If not, it is very simple,' went on Oblonsky, gradually overcoming his embarrassment.
Alexey Alejandrovich, con el rostro contraído por la emoción, murmuró algo para sus adentros; pero no contestó.
Karenin, his face drawn with distress, muttered something to himself and made no reply.
Lo que a su cuñado le parecía tan sencillo, él lo había pensado mil veces; y no sólo no le parecía muy sencillo, sino completamente imposible.
He had considered a thousand times all this which appeared so simple to Oblonsky, and it seemed to him not only far from simple but altogether impossible.

El divorcio, cuyos detalles de realización conocía ahora, parecíale a la sazón inaceptable, porque el sentimiento de su propia dignidad y la religión que profesaba le impedían tomar sobre sí la responsabilidad de un adulterio ficticio.

An action for divorce, with the details of which he was now acquainted, seemed impossible, because a feeling of self-respect and his regard for religion would not allow him to plead guilty to a fictitious act of adultery, and still less to allow the wife he had forgiven and whom he loved to be indicted and disgraced.
Y menos aún podía tolerar que la mujer amada y a quien había perdonado, fuese inculpada y cubierta de oprobio.
Luego, el divorcio aparecía también como iniposible por otras causas más trascendentales aún.
¿Qué sería de su hijo si se divorciaban?
For other and yet more important reasons also, divorce seemed out of the question.
Dejarle con su madre era imposible.
La madre divorciada tendría su propia familia ilegítima, y en ella la situación y educación del hijastro tenían que ser malas forzosamente.
In case of a divorce, what would become of his son?
¿Retener a su hijo consigo?
To leave him with his mother was not possible; the divorced mother would have another, an illegitimate family, in which the position and education of a stepson would in all probability be a bad one.
Should he keep him himself?
Habría sido una venganza por su parte y no lo deseaba.
Y, además, el divorcio parecía aún más imposible a Karenin pensando que, al consentir en él, causaba con ello la perdición de Ana.
He knew that would be revengeful and he did not wish for revenge.
But besides all this, what made divorce seem to Karenin more impossible than any other course was that by consenting to it he would by that very act ruin Anna.

Habían llegado al fondo de su alma las palabras que le dijera Dolly en Moscú, cuando afirmó que, al optar por el divorcio, Karenin no pensaba más que en sí mismo y causaba la ruina definitiva de su mujer.
What Dolly had said in Moscow, to the effect that in considering a divorce he was thinking of himself and not of Anna, who would then be irretrievably lost, had sunk into his heart.
Y él, uniendo estas palabras a su perdón y a su cariño a los pequeños, las entendía ahora a su manera.
And having connected these words with his forgiveness and with his attachment to the children, he now understood them in his own way.
Consentir en el divorcio, dejar libre a Ana, significaba, a su juicio, prescindir de lo último que le hacía amar la vida: los niños, a los que tanto quería.

To agree to a divorce – to give her her freedom – would mean, as he looked at it, to deprive himself of the only thing that bound him to life, the children he loved, and to deprive her of the last support on the path of virtue and cast her to perdition.
As a divorced wife she would form a union with Vronsky which would be both illegal and criminal, because according to the law of the Church a wife may not remarry as long as her husband is living.
Y para ella representaba quitarle el último apoyo en el camino del bien y empujarla hacia el abismo.

Si Ana se convertía en una mujer divorciada, Karenin sabía que iría a reunirse con Vronsky en unas relaciones ilícitas y antirreligiosas, porque para la mujer, según la religión, no puede haber otro esposo mientras el primero vive.

'She will form a union with him and within a year or two he will either abandon her or she will unite with someone else;' thought Karenin; 'and I, by consenting to an illegal divorce, shall be the cause of her ruin.'
«Ana se unirá a él y, de aquí a dos o tres años, él la abandonará, o ella tendrá relaciones con otro», pensaba Alexey Alejandrovich.
«Y yo, consintiendo en ese ilícito divorcio, habré sido causa de su perdición.»
Hundreds of times he had thought it over and had come to the conclusion that a divorce was not merely less simple than his brother-in-law considered it, but quite out of the question.
Sí, lo pensaba muchas veces y se persuadía de que la cuestión del divorcio, no sólo no era muy sencilla, como decía su cuñado, sino completamente imposible.

He did not believe a word of what Oblonsky was saying, and for all his arguments had scores of refutations ready; yet he listened, feeling that those words expressed that coarse and mighty power which overruled his life and to which he would have to submit.

No creía en ninguna de las palabras de Oblonsky, se le ocurrían mil objeciones a cada una y, con todo, le escuchaba, sintiendo que en ellas se expresaba aquella fuerza incontrastable y enorme que guiaba ahora su vida y a la que tenía que obedecer.
'The only question is, on what conditions you will agree to a divorce.
–La única cuestión es saber en qué condiciones consientes en el divorcio.
She does not want anything, does not ask for anything, but leaves all to your generosity.'
Ella no desea nada, nada se atreve a pedirte y confía en tu bondad.
'O God, O God!

How have I deserved this?' thought Karenin, recalling the particulars of a divorce-suit in which the husband took all the blame on himself; and with the same ashamed gesture with which Vronsky had covered his face, he hid his own in his hands.
«¡Dios mío, Dios mío, qué terrible castigo!», pensaba Karenin recordando los detalles sobre el modo de plantear el divorcio cuando el marido se achacaba la culpa.
Y, con el mismo ademán con que Oblonsky se ocultaba el rostro, escondió él el suyo entre las manos.
'You are upset.
I quite understand.
–Estás conmovido; lo comprendo...
But if you consider...'
Pero, si lo piensas bien...
'Whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other also... and if any man will take away thy coat, let him have thy cloak also,' thought Karenin.
«Al que te hiere la mejilla izquierda, preséntale la derecha; al que te quite el caftán, dale la camisa», recordó Alexey Alejandrovich.
'Yes, yes!' he cried in a shrill voice.
–Bien –exclamó con voz aguda– tomaré toda la responsabilidad sobre mí...
'I will take the disgrace, and even give up my son... but... but had we not better let it alone?
Hasta les daré mi hijo...
Pero ¿no valdría más dejarlo todo como está?
However, do as you like!' and turning away so that his brother-in-law should not see his face, he sat down on a chair by the window.
En fin, haz lo que quieras...
Y volviéndose de espaldas a su cuñado a fin de que éste no le pudiese ver, se sentó en una silla cerca de la ventana.
It was very bitter, and he felt ashamed; yet mixed with the bitterness and the shame he felt a sense of joy and emotion at the greatness of his own humility.
Sentía una gran amargura y una profunda vergüenza, pero junto con aquella vergüenza y aquella amargura, se sentía enternecido y gozoso por su propia humildad tan elevada.
Oblonsky was touched.
He remained silent for a while.
'Alexis Alexandrovich!
–Créeme, Alexey Alejandrovich, Ana apreciará mucho tu bondad.
Believe me, she will esteem your generosity,' said he.
Pero se ve que ésta era la voluntad divina –añadió.
'But evidently it was God's will,' he added, and having said it felt how silly it was and could hardly help smiling at his own stupidity.
Y una vez que hubo dicho tales palabras, se dio cuenta de que eran una tontería, y apenas pudo contener una sonrisa pensando en su propia necedad.
Karenin would have answered, but could not for his tears.
Alexey Alejandrovich quiso contestar, pero las lágrimas se lo impidieron.
'It is a fatal disaster and has to be faced.
–Es una desgracia inevitable y hay que aceptarla.
I regard this disaster as an accomplished fact and am trying to help both you and her,' Oblonsky went on.
Acéptala como un hecho consumado, procurando ayudar a Ana y ayudarte a ti mismo –dijo Esteban Arkadievich.

When he left his brother-in-law's room Oblonsky was touched, but this feeling did not spoil his contentment at having successfully arranged the matter, for he was certain that Alexis Alexandrovich would not go back on his word.

Cuando salió de la habitación de su cuñado, estaba profundamente conmovido, pero ello no le impedía sentirse alegre por haber logrado resolver aquel asunto, pues tenía el convencimiento de que Karenin no rectificaría sus palabras.
To his contentment was added an idea that had just occurred to him.
When the affair was all settled he would ask his wife and intimate friends a riddle: 'What is the difference between me and a chemist?'
A su satisfacción se unía el pensamiento de que, cuando el asunto quedara terminado, podría decir a su mujer y a los amigos: «¿En qué nos diferenciamos un mariscal y yo?
Answer: 'A chemist makes solutions which do not make anyone happy, but I have made a dissolution and made three people happy!'
En que el mariscal dirige la parada de la guardia, sin beneficio de nadie, y yo he conseguido un divorcio en beneficio de tres».
Or, 'Why am I like a chemist?...
O bien: «¿En qué nos parecemos un mariscal y yo?
When...
En que ...». « ¡Bah!
However, I will improve on it later,' he said to himself with a smile.
Ya se me ocurrirá algo mejor», se dijo Oblonsky, sonriendo.
CHAPTER XXIII
XXIII
ALTHOUGH VRONSKY'S wound had missed the heart it was dangerous, and for several days he lay between life and death.
La herida de Vronsky era peligrosa y, aunque la bala no había alcanzado el corazón, el herido estuvo varios días luchando entre la vida y la muerte.
When he was first able to talk again his brother's wife Varya was alone with him.
Cuando pudo hablar por primera vez, únicamente Varia, la mujer de su hermano, estaba junto al lecho.
'Varya!' he said looking sternly at her, 'it went off accidentally!
–Varia –dijo él, mirándola con gravedad–: el arma se me disparó por un descuido.
Never speak of it, please, and tell everybody else that.
Te ruego que no me hables nunca de esto.
Y dilo a todos así.
Or else it would be too stupid.'
Otra cosa sería demasiado estúpida.
Without saying a word Varya bent over him and looked in his face with a joyful smile.
Varia, sin contestarle, se inclinó hacia él y le miró a la cara con una sonrisa de contento.
His eyes were clear and no longer feverish, but their expression was stern.
Los ojos de Vronsky eran ahora claros, sin fiebre, pero en ellos se dibujaba una expresión severa.
'Well, thank God!' she exclaimed.
–¡Gracias a Dios! –exclamó Varia–.
'You are not in pain?'
¿Te duele algo?
'A little, here,' and he pointed to his chest.
Y Vronsky indicaba el pecho. –Un poco aquí.
'Then let me change the bandage.'
–Voy a anudarte mejor la venda.
He looked at her silently, his broad jaws set, while she bandaged him.
Vronsky, en silencio, apretando con fuerza las recias mandi'bulas, la miraba mientras ella le arreglaba el vendaje.
When she had finished he said.
Cuando terminó, Vronsky dijo:
'I am not delirious...
–Oye: no deliro.
Please arrange so that no one shall say that I shot myself on purpose.'
Y te ruego que procures que, cuando se hable de esto, no se diga que disparé deliberadamente.
'But no one does say so.
–Nadie lo dice.
Only I hope you will not go letting it off accidentally any more,' said she with an inquiring smile.
Pero espero que no vuelvas a tener un descuido –repuso ella con interrogativa sonrisa.
'I expect I shan't, but it would have been better...' and he smiled gloomily.
–No lo haré, probablemente, pero más habría valido que...
Y Vronsky sonrió con tristeza.
Despite these words and that smile, which greatly perturbed Varya, when the inflammation left him and he became convalescent he felt that he had rid himself entirely of one part of his grief.
Pese a tales palabras y a la sonrisa que tanto asustara a Varia, cuando la inflamación cesó, el herido, reponiéndose, se sintió libre de una parte de sus penas.
By his action he seemed to have washed off the shame and degradation he had previously felt.
Con lo que había hecho, parecíale haber borrado parcialmente la vergüenza y la humillación que experimentara antes.
Now he could think quietly about Karenin, fully realizing his generosity without being humiliated thereby.
Besides that, he got into his old rut again.
Ahora podía pensar con más serenidad en Alexey Alejandrovich, de quien reconocía toda la grandeza de alma sin sentirse, sin embargo, rebajado por ella.
He found he could look people in the face once more, and he was able to live in accord with his former habits.
Podía además, mirar a la gente a la cara sin avergonzarse, reanudar su habitual género de existencia, vivir con arreglo a sus costumbres.
The one thing he could not tear out of his heart, although he continually struggled against it, was a regret bordering on despair at having lost Anna for ever.
Lo único que no podía arrancar de su alma, a pesar de que luchaba constantemente contra este sentimiento que le sumía en la desesperación, era el haber perdido a Ana.

That now, having atoned for his guilt toward her husband, he would be obliged to give her up and never place himself between her with her remorse and her husband, was clear to his mind; but he could not eradicate from his heart a regret for the loss of her love – could not efface from his memory the moments of happiness he had known with her, moments he had valued so lightly, but the image of which with all their charm pursued him still.

Ahora, expiaba su falta ante Karenin, estaba, es verdad, firmemente resuelto a no interponerse nunca entre la esposa arrepentida y su marido; pero no podía arrancar de su alma la pena de haber perdido su amor; no podía borrar de su memoria los momentos pasados con Ana, que antes apreciara en tan poco, y cuyo recuerdo le perseguía ahora incesantemente.
Serpukhovskoy thought out a post for him in Tashkend and Vronsky accepted the proposition without the least hesitation.
Serpujovskoy le había buscado un destino en Tachkent y Vronsky lo había aceptado sin la menor vacilación.
But the nearer the hour for his departure approached the harder seemed the sacrifice he was making to what he considered his duty.
Pero, a medida que se acercaba el momento de partir, tanto más penoso le resultaba el sacrificio que ofrecía a lo que consideraba su deber.
His wound was quite healed and he went about making preparations for his journey to Tashkend.
La herida quedó curada.
Empezó a salir y a realizar sus preparativos de viaje a Tachkent.
'Only to see her once more, and then to bury myself, to die!' he thought, as he was making a round of farewell calls, and he expressed this thought to Betsy.
«Quiero verla una vez y luego desaparecer, morir ...», pensaba Vronsky, mientras hacía sus visitas de despedida.
It was with this message that Betsy went to Anna, and she brought him an answer in the negative.
Expresó aquel pensamiento a Betsy.
Ésta lo transmitió a Ana y volvió con una respuesta negativa.
'So much the better,' thought Vronsky when he heard it.
«Tanto mejor», se dijo Vronsky, al saberlo.
'It would have been a weakness – would have taken away all the strength I have left.'
«Era una debilidad que habría consumido mis últimas fuerzas.»
Next day Betsy herself came and announced that she had received, through Oblonsky, the definite news that Karenin consented to a divorce and that therefore Vronsky might see Anna.
Al día siguiente, por la mañana, Betsy fue a su casa y le manifestó que había recibido por Oblonsky la afirmación de que Karenin entablaba el divorcio.
Y por tanto, Vronsky podía ver a Ana.

Without so much as taking the trouble of seeing Betsy to the door, or of asking when he could see Anna and where her husband was, Vronsky, in spite of all his resolutions, at once went to the Karenins'.
Without seeing anyone or anything he ran up the stairs and entered her room with hurried steps – almost at a run.

Olvidándose incluso de acompañar a Betsy hasta la puerta, olvidándose de todas sus resoluciones, sin preguntar cuándo podía visitarla ni dónde estaba el marido, Vronsky se dirigió inmediatamente a casa de los Karenin.
Without thinking, or considering whether they were alone or not, he embraced her and covered her face, hands, and neck with kisses.
Subió corriendo la escalera, sin ver nada ni a nadie, y con paso rápido, conteniéndose para no seguir corriendo, pasó a la habitación de Ana.
Anna had prepared herself for this meeting and had thought about what she would say to him; but she had no time to say any of it, seized by his passion.
Sin reflexionar, sin mirar si había o no alguien en la habitación, Vronsky la estrechó contra su pecho y cubrió de besos su rostro, manos y garganta.
She wished to calm him and herself, but it was too late.
Ana estaba preparada para recibirle y había pensado en lo que le debía hablar, pero no tuvo tiempo para decirle nada de lo que había pensado.
His passion communicated itself to her.
La pasión de él la arrebató.
Habría querido calmarse, pero era tarde ya.
Her lip trembled so that for a long time she could not speak.
El mismo sentimiento de Vronsky se le había comunicado a ella.
'Yes, you have taken possession of me and I am yours,' she brought out at last, pressing his hands to her bosom.
Sus labios temblaban y durante largo rato no pudo hablar. –Te has adueñado de mí...
Soy tuya... –murmuró al fin, oprimiéndole el pecho con las manos.
'It had to be!' said he.
–Tenía que ser así –respondió Vronsky–.
'As long as we live it will have to be.
Mientras vivamos, tiene que ser así.
Now I am sure of it.'
Ahora lo comprendo.
'It is true,' she said, growing paler and paler, putting her arms about his head.
–Es verdad ––dijo Ana, palideciendo cada vez más y besándole la cabeza–.
'Still, there is something terrible in this, after what has been.'
Pero de todos modos, esto, después de lo sucedido, es terrible.
'It will pass, it will all pass, and we shall be so happy!
–Todo pasará...
¡Todo pasará y seremos felices!
If our love could be stronger, there being something terrible in it would make it so,' he said, raising his head with a smile that showed his fine teeth.
Nuestro amor, después de todo eso, ha crecido, si cabe, por terrible que sea –afirmó Vronsky, alzando la cabeza y mostrando al sonreír, sus fuertes dientes.
She could not help smiling in answer, not to his words but to his enamoured eyes.
Y Ana no pudo contestarle ni con palabras ni con una sonrisa, sino con la expresión amorosa de sus ojos.
She took his hand and stroked with it her cold cheek and cropped hair.
Luego tomó la mano de Vronsky a hizo que la acariciase sus mejillas frías y sus cabellos cortados.
'I don't know you with this short hair!
–Con el cabello corto no pareces la misma...
You have improved so, you little boy! – But how pale you are!'
Te encuentro guapa; pareces una niña...
Pero ¡qué pálida estás!
'Yes, I feel very weak,' she said with a smile, and her lip trembled again.
–Me siento muy débil –respondió Ana sonriendo.
Y sus labios temblaron otra vez.
'We will go to Italy and you will soon get well,' said he.
–Iremos a Italia y allí te repondrás –dijo él.
'Is it possible that we shall be like husband and wife, alone, a family, you and I?' she said, looking closely into his eyes.
–¿Es posible que vivamos juntos, como esposos, formando una familia? –repuso Ana, mirándole muy de cerca a los ojos.
'I am only surprised that it could ever have been otherwise.'
–Lo único que me extraña es que antes haya sido posible lo contrario ––contestó Vronsky.
'Steve says he will agree to anything, but I cannot accept his generosity,' she said dreamily, gazing past Vronsky's face.
–Stiva dice que «él» consiente en todo, pero no puedo aceptar su magnanimidad –indicó Ana, mirando a otro lado, melancólicamente–.
'I don't want a divorce.
No quiero el divorcio.
Nothing matters to me now.
Todo me da igual.
Only I don't know what to decide about Serezha.'
Sólo me preocupa lo que va a decidir respecto a Sergio.
He was quite unable to understand how she could, at the moment of their first reunion, think about her son and divorce.
Vronsky no comprendía que, aun en aquella entrevista, Ana pensase en su hijo y en el divorcio...
As if all that were not immaterial!
¿Qué le importaba todo aquello?
'Don't talk and don't think about it' he said, playing with her hand and trying to draw her attention to himself; but she continued to gaze past him.
–No hables de eso, ni lo pienses ––dijo atrayendo hacia sí la mano de su amada para que se ocupase sólo de él.
Pero Ana no le miraba.
'Oh, why did I not die?
–¿Por qué no habré muerto?
Habría sido mejor –dijo ella–.
It would have been best!' she said, the tears streaming noiselessly down her cheeks; but unwilling to pain him, she tried to smile.
Y lágrimas silenciosas corrieron por sus mejillas.
Mas se sobrepuso y procuró sonreír para no entristecerle.
To refuse the flattering offer of a post at Tashkend, which was a dangerous one, would have seemed disgraceful and impossible according to Vronsky's former views.
Según las antiguas ideas de Vronsky, renunciar al puesto de ventaja y peligro que le ofrecían en Tachkent era vergonzoso e imposible.
But now without a moment's hesitation he did refuse it and, observing that his superiors frowned upon his action, at once resigned his commission.
Pero ahora renunció a él sin un titubeo y, notando que en las altas esferas le desaprobaban, pidió el retiro.
A month later Karenin and his son were left alone in the house, and Anna went abroad with Vronsky – not only without getting a divorce but having resolutely refused it.
Un mes más tarde, Ana y Vronsky marchaban al extranjero.
Karenin quedó solo en su casa con su hijo.
Había renunciado al divorcio para siempre.
